Description: A quality control tool for high throughput raw sequence data.
Features: It generates quality reports for NGS data and gives pass/fail results for the following checks: Per base sequence quality, Per sequence quality scores, Per base sequence content, Per base GC content, Per sequence GC content, Per base N content, Sequence length distribution, Sequence duplication levels, Overrepresented sequences, Kmer content. It also has a Graphic User Interface.
Strength: It is easy to use; provides visualization in HTML reports; can be used on Illumina, PacBio, 454 reads.
{\"value\" : \"single-end\" , \"text\":: single-ended;  {"value":"paired-end", "text":"Apply to forward and reverse strands separately."}

Description: The FASTX-Toolkit is a collection of command line tools for short-reads FASTA/FASTQ files preprocessing.
Features: The sub-command "fastx_trimmer" can be used to shorten reads (removing barcodes or noise) in FASTQ files . The sub-command "fastqx_clipper" can remove sequencing adapters or linkers.
Strength: Besides "fastx_trimmer" and "fastx_clipper" in this toolkit, there are multiple tools and commands for processing FASTA/FASTQ files. It can also be integrated and used on the web-based bioinformatics platform Galaxy.
Limitation: Last updated in 2010. {"value": "Be ware of the older base quality encoding. ", "link" : "https://wikis.utexas.edu/display/bioiteam/FASTQ+Manipulation+Tools" }

Description: A flexible read trimming tool for Illumina NGS data.
Features: It can trim adapter sequences, remove low-quality reads and bases.
Strength: It is designed as more pair-aware for paired-end data. The authors found trimmomatic to run faster than cutadapt and FASTX-Toolkit.  ({"value":"see Trimmomatic paper","link":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4103590/"})

Description: Cutadapt finds and removes adapter sequences, primers, poly-A tails and other types of unwanted sequences from high-throughput sequencing reads.
Features: Cutadapt helps with various trimming tasks by finding the adapter or primer sequences in an error-tolerant way. It can also modify and filter reads in various ways. Adapter sequences can contain IUPAC wildcard characters. Also, paired-end reads and even colorspace data are supported. If you want, you can also just demultiplex your input data, without removing adapter sequences at all ({"value":"see manual","link":"https://media.readthedocs.org/pdf/cutadapt/stable/cutadapt.pdf"}).
Strength: It supports 454, Illumina and SOLiD (colour space) data. It is used inside another tool called {"value":"Trim Galore","text":"https://www.bioinformatics.babraham.ac.uk/projects/trim_galore/"}, also a quality control tool by the FastQC team.

Description: An ultrafast memory-efficient short read aligner.
Features: It uses Burrows-Wheeler transform to create a permanent, reusable index of the genome.
Strength: It aligns short DNA sequences (reads) to the human genome at a rate of over 25 million 35-bp reads per hour. Bowtie indexes the genome with a Burrows-Wheeler index to keep its memory footprint small: typically about 2.2 GB for the human genome (2.9 GB for paired-end; {"value":"see Bowtie page", "link":"http://bowtie-bio.sourceforge.net/index.shtml"}). For relatively short reads (e.g. less than 50 bp) Bowtie 1 is sometimes faster and/or more sensitive than Bowtie 2. {"value":"link","link":"http://bowtie-bio.sourceforge.net/bowtie2/faq.shtml"}
Limitation: It does not support gapped alignments; there is an upper limit on read length (1024 bp).
Format_input: FASTQ, FASTA, Raw sequence per line
Format_output: Bowtie output (one alignment per line), SAM/BAM

Description: Bowtie 2 is an ultrafast and memory-efficient tool for aligning sequencing reads to long reference sequences.
Features: Bowtie2 first extracts "seed" substrings in reads, aligns seeds in an ungapped way, and then performs extension in a gapped way.
Strength: Bowtie 2 supports gapped, local, and paired-end alignment modes. It indexes the genome with an FM Index to keep its memory footprint small: for the human genome, its memory footprint is typically around 3.2 GB. For reads longer than about 50 bp, Bowtie 2 is generally faster, more sensitive, and uses less memory than Bowtie 1. It is particularly good at aligning reads of about 50 up to 100s or 1,000s of characters, and good at aligning to relatively long (i.e. mammalian) genomes.  {"value":"see Bowtie2 page","link":"http://bowtie-bio.sourceforge.net/bowtie2/index.shtml"}
Limitation: For relatively short reads (e.g. less than 50 bp) Bowtie 1 is sometimes faster and more sensitive than Bowtie 2. {"value":"see this","link":"http://bowtie-bio.sourceforge.net/bowtie2/faq.shtml"}
Format_input: FASTQ, QSEQ, FASTA, Raw sequence per line
Format_output: Bowtie output (one alignment per line), SAM/BAM

Description: BWA is a software package for mapping low-divergent sequences against a large reference genome.
Features: BWA uses a Burrows-Wheeler transform to create an index of the genome. It consists of three algorithms: BWA-backtrack, BWA-SW and BWA-MEM. The first algorithm is designed for Illumina sequence reads up to 100bp, while the rest two for longer sequences ranged from 70bp to 1Mbp. {"value":"link","link":"http://bio-bwa.sourceforge.net/bwa.shtml"}
Strength: BWA allows indels in alignment. BWA is used by {"value":"ENCODE DNase-seq pipeline", "link":"https://github.com/ENCODE-DCC/dnase_pipeline"} and {"value":"ENCODE ChIP-seq pipeline","link":"https://github.com/ENCODE-DCC/chip-seq-pipeline"}.

Description: SAMtools: Utilities for the Sequence AlignmentMap (SAM) format.
Features: SAMtools has multiple commands for processing SAM/BAM files. The sub-command "SAMtools-flagstat" can be used to print statistics for SAM/BAM files using the {"value":"FLAG field","link":"https://samtools.github.io/hts-specs/SAMv1.pdf"}.

Description: Picard is a set of command line tools for manipulating high-throughput sequencing (HTS) data and formats such as SAM/BAM/CRAM and VCF.
Features: It can summarize mapping statistics such as insert size, mapping score summary, and quality score summary. In particular, the subcommand Picard-MarkDuplicates can be used to remove duplicates.
Limitation: MarkDuplicates uses coordinate information but not read sequence information.

Description: CHANCE (CHip-seq ANalytics and Confidence Estimation)
Features: ChIP-seq quality control and protocol optimization.
Strength: It can assesse the strength and bias of immunoprecipitation (IP) enrichment compared to control.

Description: Model based analysis of ChIP-seq (MACS).
Features: It identifies genome-wide profiles of transcription factor binding sites or histone modification from ChIP-seq data; uses the read strand information with a local Poission model.
Strength: MACS can be ran in two modes: narrow mode for transcription factors and broad mode for histone modifications. It is used in {"value":"ENCODE ChIP-seq pipeline","link":"https://github.com/ENCODE-DCC/chip-seq-pipeline"} and {"value":"Cistrome", "link": "http://cistrome.org/"}.
Good for ChIP target: {\"value\":\"TF\",: good for {"value":"TF","text":"Used in ENCODE TF ChIP-seq pipeline"}, {"value":"histone","text":"Used in ENCODE histone ChIP-seq pipeline"}.

Description: An R package for analysis of ChIP-seq and other functional sequencing data.
Features: It accounts for the offset in forward-strand and reverse-strand reads to improve resolution, compares enrichment in signal to background or control experiments, and can also estimate whether the available number of reads is sufficient to achieve saturation, meaning that additional reads would not allow identification of additional peaks ({"value":"see ENCODE resources","link":"https://genome.ucsc.edu/encode/encodeTools.html" }).
Strength: It is used in {"value":"ENCODE ChIP-seq pipeline","link":"https://github.com/ENCODE-DCC/chip-seq-pipeline"}, for transcription factor peak calling.
Good for ChIP target: {\"value\":\"TF\",: good for {"value":"TF","text":"used in ENCODE ChIP-seq pipeline"}
Format_input: SAM/BAM, Bowtie format, MAQ format, Arachne format, tagAlign format

Description: Genome wide Event finding and Motif discovery
Features: GEM can decompose single observed peaks into multiple binding events, determine binding event location at high spatial resolution, and discover explanatory DNA sequence motifs with an integrated model of ChIP reads and proximal DNA sequences ({"value":"GEM on ENCODE","link":"https://www.encodeproject.org/software/gem/"}). It can be ran in single-condition mode or multi-condition mode; can also be used for ChIP-seq, ChIP-exo, CLIP-seq and Branch-seq data, single-end or paired-end; can also be used for de novo motif discovery ({"value":"GEM","link":"http://groups.csail.mit.edu/cgs/gem/"}).
Strength: GEM can detect more peak containing motif (benchmarked by  {"value":"Thomas et al., (2016) Briefings in Bioinformatics","link":"https://academic.oup.com/bib/article/18/3/441/2453291"}); can reach high spatial resolution for peak calling; used by ENCODE 3 uniform peak calling pipeline {"value":"GEM on ENCODE","link":"https://www.encodeproject.org/software/gem/"}.
Good for ChIP target: {\"value\":\"TF\",: good for {"value":"TF","text":"used in ENCODE ChIP-seq pipeline"}

Description: PeakSeq is a program for identifying and ranking peak regions in ChIP-Seq experiments.
Features: It uses a 2-pass approach taking into consideration of genomics mappability and control experiment.
Good for ChIP target: {\"value\":\"TF\",: good for {"value":"TF","text":"used in ENCODE ChIP-seq pipeline"}

Description: Zero-Inflated Negative Binomial Algorithm
Features: ZINBA identifies genomic regions enriched in a variety of ChIP-seq experiments, calling both broad and narrow modes of enrichment across a range of signal-to-noise ratios.
Strength: ZINBA models and accounts for factors that co-vary with background or experimental signal, such as G/C content.

Description: Bayesian Analysis of ChIP-seq Data
Features: It uses a fully Bayesian hidden Markov model to detect enriched locations in the genome.

Description: Software for motif discovery and next-gen sequencing analysis (Homer)
Features: It has 7 basic operations: factor, histone, super (super enhancer ), groseq, tss, dnase, mC(DNA methylation). It assumes the local density of tags in the data follows a Poisson distribution. Input of control data is highly recommended.
Strength: Homer suite in general has a good tutorial to follow.
Limitation: It can also be used on DNase-seq, GRO-seq, CAGE, DNA methylation data.

Description: ROC-AUC maximizing detection filter (DFilter)
Features: It needs positive training sets that can be estimated from the dataset. Based on the positive sets, it constructs filters to detect signal above the noise which is assumed Gaussian distribution.
Strength: It can be used on histone and TF ChIP-seq, DNase-seq and FAIRE-seq data.

Description: A feature density estimator for high-throughput sequence tags.
Features: A kernel density method; It was initially designed for DNase-seq data but can also be used for ChIP-seq and other data, with the parameter shift distance estimated.

Description: A fast saturation-based ChIP-seq and ChIP-nexus peak caller.
Features: It can be run with or without control data; Duplicated reads are removed on the fly by the software.
Strength: Faster than methods like SPP; It can also be used as a peak caller for ChIP-nexus data.
Good for ChIP target: {\"value\":\"TF\",: TF or {"value": "H3K4me3", "text":  "Tested in the original paper"}

Description: Identification of closely spaced TF binding sites at high resolution
Features: It is designed to resolve individual binding sites even if spaced closely; Designed for TF data but not histone modification data; Model number of reads from positive and negative strand as Gaussian distributions.
Strength: It can be used on ChIP-seq or ChIP-exo data.

Description: A novel statistical method for quantitative comparison of multiple ChIP-seq datasets.
Features: It reuqires peaks called by peak calling softwares and models the read count in peaks as Poisson distributed.
Strength: It provides good results with default parameters when replicates are available( {"value":"Steinhauser et al., 2016","link":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5142015/"})
Good for ChIP target: {\"value\":\"TF\",: TF or histone data with biological replicates and with peaks called.

Description: DiffBind: differential binding analysis of ChIP-Seq peak data.
Features: The differential analysis in the tool can be done with DESeq, DESeq2, or edgeR.
Strength: It provides good results with default parameters when replicates are available( {"value":"Steinhauser et al., 2016","link":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5142015/"})
Good for ChIP target: {\"value\":\"TF\",: TF or histone data with biological replicates and with peaks called.

Description: A robust model for quantitative comparison of ChIP-Seq data sets
Features: It normalizes signals genome-wide, uses a locally weighted regression method, and detects differential binding with a Bayesian model.
Strength: It provides good results with default parameters with single replicates ( {"value":"Steinhauser et al., 2016","link":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5142015/"})
Good for ChIP target: {\"value\":\"TF\",: TF or histone data with no replicates and with peak called.

Description: Model-based analysis of ChIP-Seq (MACS)
Features: MACS is one widely-used peak caller. Its subcommand "bdgdiff" can be used to call differental binding events together with the command "callpeak".
Strength: It provides good results with default parameters with single replicates ( {"value":"Steinhauser et al., 2016","link":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5142015/"})
Good for ChIP target: {\"value\":\"TF\",: TF data with no replicates; No need to call peaks before running.

Description: ODIN is an HMM-based approach to detect and analyse differential peaks in pairs of ChIP-seq data.
Features: It is tailored for ChIP-seq comparison without replicates; It also call peaks using Hidden Markov Model. It model read counts as Binomial or mixed Poisson distribution.
Limitation: It may require more tuning of parameters. It tends to call a large number of small peaks for broad signals (benchmarked by {"value":"Steinhauser et al., 2016","link":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5142015/"}).
Good for ChIP target: {\"value\":\"TF\",: TF data with no replicates; No need to call peaks before running.

Description: Detecting differentially bound sharp binding sites across multiple conditions, with or without matching control samples.
Features: It uses Negative Binomial model; requires peak calling as input. Differential analysis in the tool can be done by DESeq DESeq2, or edgeR.
Limitation: It may generate insufficient number of differential regions (benchmarked by {"value":"Steinhauser et al., 2016","link":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5142015/"})

Description: MEME-ChIP: motif analysis of large DNA datasets
Features: It can perform motif discovery, motif enrichment analysis, motif visualization, binding affinity analysis, and motif identification.
Strength: It has a web interface as well as a command line version.
Limitation: For the online version, the sequence file uploaded cannot exceed 50MB. There is limitation on sequence length.

Description: Software for motif discovery and next-gen sequencing analysis (Homer)
Features: Homer contains a novel motif discovery algorithm, comparing two sets of sequences.
Strength: Homer suite in general has a good tutorial to follow.
Limitation: For the online version, the sequence file uploaded cannot exceed 50MB. There is limitation on sequence length.

Description: RSAT peak-motifs: motif analysis in full-size ChIP-seq datasets
Features: It discovers motifs in peaks sequences and compares with databases.
Strength: It has a web interface as well as a command line version; has no limitation on sequence size or number of peaks; can link to Galaxy.

Description: ChIPpeakAnno: a Bioconductor package to annotate ChIP-seq and ChIP-chip data.
Features: It retrives sequences around peaks, obtains enriched gene ontology terms, and finds the nearest gene or other features; also summarizes motifs in peaks.

Description: Gene Ontology enrichment analysis
Features: It performs enrichment analysis on gene sets; performs functional analysis including molecular function, cellular component and biological process.
Strength: It has an interactive web server.

Description: The Database for Annotation, Visualization and Integrated Discovery
Features: It identifies enriched biological terms, discovers enriched functional-related genes, etc. See the {"value":"link","link":"https://david.ncifcrf.gov/home.jsp"}
Strength: It has an interactive web server.

Description: A website organizing the analysis results of ENCODE TF ChIP-seq data.
Features: Features include expressed transcripts and genomic regions bound by transcription factors (TFs), occupied by nucleosomes, occupied by nucleosomes with modified histones, or hypersensitive to DNase I cleavage, etc.
Strength: Contains graphical presentations of TF function, histone profiles, motif enrichment, histone heatmaps, TF heatmaps, nucleosome profiles.
Limitation: Note that the motif enrichment analysis was done using top 500 peaks.
